explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required for analyzing MISRA "for loop shall be well-formed" for OS_SocketBind:

- OS_SocketBindAddress: Direct callee. Must inspect its implementation (and whether it is a macro/inline) to ensure it does not expand into or introduce a for-loop that would be considered part of the caller’s code or otherwise affect loop-counter rules via inlining/side-effects.

- OS_SocketListen: Direct callee. Same reason as above — its body (or inline/macro form) must be checked for any for-loops or side-effects that could interact with any for-loop in the caller.

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType: Appears in the target’s static call graph (test/stub instrumentation). Stubs/wrappers can be substituted for real calls or be inlined; their definitions must be checked to ensure they do not contain/introduce for-loops or side-effects that would affect conformance.

- UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData: Same as above — include because instrumentation stubs may be present and could change the effective code seen by static analysis.

- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler: Same as above — this stub/handler may be invoked in place of real implementations; inspect to ensure it does not add for-loops or modify objects used as loop counters.

- UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: Same as above — include any testing/stub helpers that the call graph shows as possible callees.

- osal_id_t: Type of the sock_id parameter. Needed to resolve whether the parameter is a simple scalar (so cannot be used as a loop counter implicitly) or a more complex type (e.g., macro/struct) that could hide side-effects or aliasing relevant to loop-counter rules.

- OS_SockAddr_t: Type of the Addr parameter. Included so the analyzer can see if its definition contains macros/inline functions or side-effecting expressions that could interact with for-loop criteria when used by callees or in any inlined code.

- int32: Local variable type (return_code). Include the typedef/definition so the analyzer knows whether this is a plain integer type and cannot be (via macro) something that would affect loop semantics.

- OS_SUCCESS: Return-code constant used in conditional checks. Needed to understand control flow (which callees are invoked) and to ensure no hidden macros expand to loops.

- OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE: Return-code constant used in conditional checks (special-case handled). Included to fully resolve the control-flow decisions that determine which callees execute.

Note: OS_SocketBind itself contains no for-loop. The primary reason to include the callees and stub helpers is to confirm none of them are implemented as macros/inline functions (or are substituted by test stubs) that would effectively introduce a for-loop into the caller context or otherwise produce side-effects relevant to the MISRA for-loop well-formedness rule.
